introMethod1.value:
Your high school yearbook photo is
a moment frozen in time. For some, it’s a moment they’d rather forget, but for us, it’s data.

introMethod2.value:
We looked at over 30,000 pictures from 1930–2013 to find out when
big hair was at its height.

dimensionText1.value:
Using a deep learning method,
we mapped the images into
a 4-dimensional space.

dimensionText2.value: This gives us a unique fingerprint for each hair shape. Here’s what that looks like for three popular styles...

styleText1.value: We then trained neural network classifiers to see how these looks trended over time.

straightText.value: And long straight hair was replaced by 1980s perms.

avgGridText1.value: Let’s take a closer look at the 1980s, did big hair really dominate the decade? Here are 10 photos that represent the most average hairstyle by decade.

avgGridText2.value: And here’s what that looks like when we split it by gender…

trendText1.value: By calculating the density of hair pixels in each picture, we can roughly estimate how much hair is present and get a median hair size for each decade.

trendNote1.value: Women’s hair was the shortest in the 1930s, when short finger waves were popular.

trendNote2.value: Men’s hair was the shortest in the decades following World War II, when many sported military crew cuts.

trendNote3.value: And for both women and men, hair size did peak in the late 70s and early 80s.

trendText2.value: All that big hair also meant that women and men’s styles were more similar than ever before.

discrimNote1.value: Women’s and men’s hairstyles were least similar post WWII when men’s short buzzes were contrasted with women’s high roll curls.

discrimNote2.value: And they were most similar in the 1980s when big hairspray reigned supreme.

discrimNote3.value: Today, women’s and men’s styles are less similar than anytime in the past 30 years.

outro1.value: This doesn’t mean that we’re not seeing more gender neutral hairstyles today — just that there are more polarizing styles like long or short crops.

outro2.value: Whatever the style trends, we’re all sure to laugh at our photos in the next decade.
